awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Sustainable Engineering of Lightweight Aggregate for Concrete Use from Waste Coal Combustion Ash
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is two-folds: (1) increasing the accessibility of construction lightweight aggregate (LWA) for the concrete industry and (2) conversion of waste coal combustion ash (W-CCA) to value-added products (i.e., construction LWA). Yearly, about 100 million tons of coal combustion ash is produced in the US, of which only about 60% is recycled and the rest is moved to the landfills. This imposes risks to human health and the environment. Meanwhile, accessibility of construction LWA that is traditionally produced from clay, slate, and shale is challenging for the concrete industry in some states due to the absence of local construction LWA manufacturers. Therefore, LWA must be imported from elsewhere in the country, increasing (i) the final cost for the material and (ii) greenhouse gas emission due to transportation. With an abundance of W-CCA landfills scattered throughout the US, LWA can be produced from this material near the landfill sites to increase the local accessibility of construction LWA for the concrete industry. By implementing this technology, the environmental impact of W-CCA will be reduced, natural resource consumption will be prevented, CO2 emission associated with material transportation will be reduced, and users can save money by having access to local construction LWA.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses hurdles associated with manufacturing a novel porous lightweight aggregate (LWA) produced from waste coal combustion ash (W-CCA). The melting properties of W-CCA enable the production of construction LWA with superior engineering properties, including increased water absorption/desorption capacity and concrete workability relative to traditional LWA.  The deliverables of this project include: (i) development of a LWA with desired sintering properties during pilot-scale production to assure technical feasibility of scaling-up the proposed technology, (ii) optimization of pilot-scale rotary kiln parameters translatable to large-scale production, (iii) demonstration of the superior engineering properties of LWA for concrete applications produced at lab pilot-scale, and (iv) demonstration of the non-leachability of W-CCA based LWA in encapsulated concrete applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this NSF SBIR Phase I project was to demonstrate the technical feasibility of bench scale manufacturing of engineered waste coal combustion ash (W-CCA) based Spherical Porous Lightweight Aggregate (LWA), named SPORA, produced using our thermodynamic-guided technology. SusMaX uses its predictive thermodynamics framework to design SPORA based on the chemical composition of the raw W-CCA and the required conditions for formation of a porous LWA, i.e., (1) forming the optimal amount of molten phase, (2) appropriate viscosity for partially molten ash, and (3) gas phase release from the ash to form the pores. Our thermodynamics-guided approach provides a balance for these three conditions to make sure a technically engineered LWA is produced. The goal of this project was achieved by addressing three technical challenges.

(1)     Technical Hurdle #1: Formation of liquid phase on SPORA’s surface during scale-up sintering leads to LWA adhering together and formation of large lumps obstructing the production

We implemented a surface coating of fresh SPORA using raw W-CCA that could completely resolve the agglomeration issue of SPORA during sintering to ensure smooth and continuous production. We elaborated on the mechanism of this surface coating using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis. Our SEM analysis showed that raw particles of W-CCA present on the surface of SPORA would not get melted during sintering due to higher melting point in comparison to treated particles using NaOH as our fluxing agent. The unmelted particles on the surface are responsible for preventing the SPORA spheres from adhering together and preventing agglomeration ultimately.

(2)     Technical Hurdle #2: Optimization of bench scale production of W-CCA based SPORA using palletizer and rotary kiln for the achievement of superior engineering properties

We experimentally and analytically characterized the mean residence time of sintering (MRT) based on different kiln configurations. MRT is an important parameter that can affect the engineering properties of a LWA including specific gravity, water absorption, and crushing strength. We used empirical and numerical equations for predicting MRT. The comparison between experimental and analytical MRT indicated that Chatterjee’s equation could most accurately predict the experimental values of the MRT. This finding is specifically important for us as we scale our technology so we can use this analytical model to obtain the kiln angle and rotation speed that would result in the desired MRT with minimal experimental characterization. The results also indicated that at bench scale we could successfully produce SPORA that had an oven-dry specific gravity of 1.26, 72 h water absorption of 25%, and average crushing strength of 14.7 MPa. These values were 20% lower, 200% higher, and 28% higher than that of the best-performing commercial LWA in the US market making SPORA a better choice for our potential customers.

(3)     Technical Hurdle #3: Achieving limited leachability of Constituent of Potential Concern (COPC) from W-CCA based SPORA to ensure safe use of the product

The third technical hurdle was demonstrating the limited leachability of COPC from W-CCA based SPORA to ensure the safe use of the product. We implemented LEAF 1313 approach to assess COPC leaching from raw W-CCA and SPORA under different pH values. Our evaluation indicated that while Arsenic (As) leaching from raw W-CCA passed the EPA limit for industrial wastewater, SPORA’s COPC leaching did not pass any EPA limit. More importantly, the leaching values for SPORA for many elements such as Se, Sb, and Tl were reduced compared to raw W-CCA. The reason for this reduction was related to sintering at a high temperature (1075 °C) that resulted in the formation of liquid (slag phase) that can encapsulate these elements. These findings indicate that SPORA potentially can be safely used as a construction product for concrete application.

SusMaX’s technology addresses the following broader impacts: Economic impacts on LWA supply chain and W-CCA landfills: (a) We will address the supply chain issue of LWA by locally producing SPORA close to our customers to reduce the delivered cost of LWA by more than 50%. (b) W-CCA landfills require annual budget allocation for maintenance, monitoring, and retrofitting posing a significant financial burden on coal powerplants. Additionally, improper construction of landfills has led to catastrophic events such as the Kingston Fossil Plant coal fly ash slurry spill where the estimated cleaning costs totaled $1 B. By removing and recycling the W-CCA from landfills, SusMaX will significantly reduce the risk of catastrophic landfill failures and alleviate the economic burdens on both coal powerplants and the nation.

Environmental and societal impact: According to the EPA, more than 500 W-CCA landfills are leaching toxic substances into our groundwater at levels exceeding federal safe standards due to improper landfill construction and management. The consequence of these contaminations is continuous damage to the environment, groundwater, and human health resulting in cancer. SusMaX will reduce the risk leaching from landfills.
